qa_pairs.question: What was the sequence of events leading to the founding of Leonard Green & Partners, and what were the key financial outcomes of his firm's acquisitions?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>Leonard I. Green co-founded the investment banking partnership Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen in 1969, which specialized in leveraged buyouts.<cite>[S11]</cite></statement> <statement>In 1980, he moved to California and opened a branch office, later leaving Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen in 1989 to establish Leonard Green & Partners in Los Angeles.<cite>[S12][S13]</cite></statement> <statement>Leonard Green & Partners' key financial outcomes included acquiring Thrifty Drugs for $40 million in 1992 and Payless Drugs for $1.2 billion in 1994, merging them into Thrifty Payless, which became the largest drugstore chain in the Western U.S.<cite>[S14]</cite></statement> <statement>The firm netted a $420 million profit when Thrifty Payless was sold to Rite Aid for $2.3 billion in 1996 after its initial public offering.<cite>[S16]</cite></statement> <statement>Additional acquisitions under Green's leadership included Carr-Gottstein Foods Co., Australian Resources Limited, and Big 5 Sporting Goods, though specific financial details for these were not provided.<cite>[S17]</cite></statement>
qa_pairs.chunk:
Passage 1:
[S1] Leonard I. [S2] Green


# Leonard I. [S3] Green



**Leonard I. [S4] Green** (1934–2002) was an American businessman who was the founding partner of leveraged buyout firm Leonard Green & Partners and chairman of the board of the Los Angeles Opera. [S5] ## Early life

Green was raised in Philadelphia, to a Jewish family. [S6] In 1955, he earned a B.A. [S7] in economics from Cornell University and in 1956, graduated with an M.B.A. [S8] from the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton Graduate School. [S9] In 1965, he received a Juris Doctor degree from Loyola University in Chicago. [S10] ## Career

In 1969, Green co-founded the New York investment banking partnership, *Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen,* which specialized in management-led, non-hostile leveraged buyouts. [S11] In 1980, he moved to California and opened a branch office. [S12] In 1989, he left *Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen* and founded *Leonard Green & Partners* based in Los Angeles. [S13] In 1992, Green's firm paid $40 million for Thrifty Drugs and in 1994, they purchased Payless Drugs for $1.2 billion, merging the two companies to form the largest drugstore chain in the Western U.S. [S14] with more than 1,080 outlets, Thrifty Payless. [S15] In April 1996, Thrifty Payless went public and then in October 1996, it was sold to Rite Aid for $2.3 billion netting Green's firm a $420 million profit. [S16] Other companies that the firm acquired while Green was chairman were Carr-Gottstein Foods Co., Australian Resources Limited, and Big 5 Sporting Goods. [S17] ## Philanthropy

In 1986, Green became a founding director of Los Angeles Opera serving as its president and chief executive from 1998 to 2001. [S18] He personally donated $2 million to the opera and was credited with recruiting Plácido Domingo as artistic director. [S19] Green was also a member of the board of the Music Center of Los Angeles County. [S20] ## Personal life and death

Green was married three times. [S21] In 1995, Green married his third wife, Jude Green, from Michigan; they divorced in 2000. [S22] Green has two children. [S23] Green died in 2002.
chunk_list:
[S1] Leonard I. [S2] Green


# Leonard I. [S3] Green



**Leonard I. [S4] Green** (1934–2002) was an American businessman who was the founding partner of leveraged buyout firm Leonard Green & Partners and chairman of the board of the Los Angeles Opera. [S5] ## Early life

Green was raised in Philadelphia, to a Jewish family. [S6] In 1955, he earned a B.A. [S7] in economics from Cornell University and in 1956, graduated with an M.B.A. [S8] from the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton Graduate School. [S9] In 1965, he received a Juris Doctor degree from Loyola University in Chicago. [S10] ## Career

In 1969, Green co-founded the New York investment banking partnership, *Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen,* which specialized in management-led, non-hostile leveraged buyouts. [S11] In 1980, he moved to California and opened a branch office. [S12] In 1989, he left *Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen* and founded *Leonard Green & Partners* based in Los Angeles. [S13] In 1992, Green's firm paid $40 million for Thrifty Drugs and in 1994, they purchased Payless Drugs for $1.2 billion, merging the two companies to form the largest drugstore chain in the Western U.S. [S14] with more than 1,080 outlets, Thrifty Payless. [S15] In April 1996, Thrifty Payless went public and then in October 1996, it was sold to Rite Aid for $2.3 billion netting Green's firm a $420 million profit. [S16] Other companies that the firm acquired while Green was chairman were Carr-Gottstein Foods Co., Australian Resources Limited, and Big 5 Sporting Goods. [S17] ## Philanthropy

In 1986, Green became a founding director of Los Angeles Opera serving as its president and chief executive from 1998 to 2001. [S18] He personally donated $2 million to the opera and was credited with recruiting Plácido Domingo as artistic director. [S19] Green was also a member of the board of the Music Center of Los Angeles County. [S20] ## Personal life and death

Green was married three times. [S21] In 1995, Green married his third wife, Jude Green, from Michigan; they divorced in 2000. [S22] Green has two children. [S23] Green died in 2002.

In 1989, he left that firm to start Leonard Green & Partners in Los Angeles. So the sequence is: co-founding Gibbons in 1969, moving to CA in 1980, leaving in 1989 to start his own firm.

Next, the key financial outcomes. The passage states that in 1992, the firm bought Thrifty Drugs for $40 million. Then in 1994, they bought Payless Drugs for $1.2 billion, merging them into Thrifty Payless. Then in 1996, Thrifty Payless went public and was sold to Rite Aid for $2.3 billion, giving a $420 million profit. Other acquisitions mentioned are Carr-Gottstein, Australian Resources, and Big 5 Sporting Goods, but specific financial details aren't provided for those.

I need to structure the answer with the sequence of events and the financial outcomes, citing the relevant sentences. Each sentence in the answer should have the correct citations. Let me check the sentence numbers again to make sure.

For the sequence: leaving Gibbons in 1989 to found Leonard Green & Partners is S13. The move to California in 1980 is S12. Co-founding Gibbons in 1969 is S11.

For the financial outcomes: Thrifty Drugs purchase in 1992 is S14. Payless Drugs in 1994 is S14 and S15? Then the sale to Rite Aid in 1996 is S16. The profit is mentioned in S16 as $420 million. The other acquisitions are in S17 but no financial details there.

So the answer should list the events in order with their citations and the financial outcomes with their respective citations. Need to make sure each statement is correctly cited and formatted as per the instructions.

qa_pairs.question: How did Leonard Green's business strategies in leveraged buyouts manifest in the acquisition and sale of Thrifty Payless, and what was the financial result?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>Leonard Green's business strategies in leveraged buyouts involved acquiring and merging companies to create larger entities, as seen in the 1992 acquisition of Thrifty Drugs for $40 million and the 1994 purchase of Payless Drugs for $1.2 billion, forming Thrifty Payless.<cite>[S14]</cite></statement> <statement>The financial result of this strategy was the 1996 sale of Thrifty Payless to Rite Aid for $2.3 billion, which generated a $420 million profit for Green's firm.<cite>[S16]</cite></statement>

qa_pairs.question: What educational and professional milestones did Leonard Green achieve before founding his own firm, and how did they relate to his later business ventures?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>Leonard Green earned a B.A. in economics from Cornell University in 1955 and an M.B.A. from the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton Graduate School in 1956, which provided him with foundational business and economic expertise.<cite>[S6][S7][S8]</cite></statement> <statement>He later obtained a Juris Doctor degree from Loyola University in 1965, enhancing his legal and financial acumen, which likely supported his later roles in investment banking and leveraged buyouts.<cite>[S9]</cite></statement> <statement>In 1969, Green co-founded the investment banking partnership *Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen*, specializing in management-led leveraged buyouts, which established his expertise in this niche and laid the groundwork for his future ventures.<cite>[S11]</cite></statement> <statement>By 1980, he had moved to California and expanded his operations, eventually leaving *Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen* in 1989 to establish *Leonard Green & Partners*, leveraging his prior experience in leveraged buyouts to build his own firm.<cite>[S12][S13]</cite></statement> <statement>These educational and professional milestones, particularly his work in leveraged buyouts and investment banking, directly informed his later success in acquiring and merging companies like Thrifty Drugs and Payless Drugs, solidifying his reputation as a strategic business leader.<cite>[S14][S16]</cite></statement>

His career milestones, such as founding Leonard Green & Partners in 1989 and his work with the Los Angeles Opera, are described independently of his personal life.<cite>[S13][S18]</cite></statement>
qa_pairs.chunk:
Passage 1:
[S1] Leonard I. [S2] Green


# Leonard I. [S3] Green



**Leonard I. [S4] Green** (1934–2002) was an American businessman who was the founding partner of leveraged buyout firm Leonard Green & Partners and chairman of the board of the Los Angeles Opera. [S5] ## Early life

Green was raised in Philadelphia, to a Jewish family. [S6] In 1955, he earned a B.A. [S7] in economics from Cornell University and in 1956, graduated with an M.B.A. [S8] from the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton Graduate School. [S9] In 1965, he received a Juris Doctor degree from Loyola University in Chicago. [S10] ## Career

In 1969, Green co-founded the New York investment banking partnership, *Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen,* which specialized in management-led, non-hostile leveraged buyouts. [S11] In 1980, he moved to California and opened a branch office. [S12] In 1989, he left *Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen* and founded *Leonard Green & Partners* based in Los Angeles. [S13] In 1992, Green's firm paid $40 million for Thrifty Drugs and in 1994, they purchased Payless Drugs for $1.2 billion, merging the two companies to form the largest drugstore chain in the Western U.S. [S14] with more than 1,080 outlets, Thrifty Payless. [S15] In April 1996, Thrifty Payless went public and then in October 1996, it was sold to Rite Aid for $2.3 billion netting Green's firm a $420 million profit. [S16] Other companies that the firm acquired while Green was chairman were Carr-Gottstein Foods Co., Australian Resources Limited, and Big 5 Sporting Goods. [S17] ## Philanthropy

In 1986, Green became a founding director of Los Angeles Opera serving as its president and chief executive from 1998 to 2001. [S18] He personally donated $2 million to the opera and was credited with recruiting Plácido Domingo as artistic director. [S19] Green was also a member of the board of the Music Center of Los Angeles County. [S20] ## Personal life and death

Green was married three times. [S21] In 1995, Green married his third wife, Jude Green, from Michigan; they divorced in 2000. [S22] Green has two children. [S23] Green died in 2002.
